David Gardner.Action: Uses a telescope late at night and studies star maps and nautical almanacs carefully.
Accidentally drops the aluminum canteen but quickly recovers without waking others.
Chirps at the dog Cricket, who follows him out the window.
Follows the dog toward a strange glowing light, then runs back to the house with the dog.
Bursts into parents' bedroom with flashlight to alert them about what he saw.
Excitedly shares his sighting of a flying saucer with his parents despite their disbelief.
Slams the door in frustration after being dismissed.
Turns and looks at his father guiltily after being sent to bed.
Insists multiple times to his parents that he saw a flying saucer despite their disbelief.
Behaves excitedly and somewhat impatiently, slamming the door when dismissed.
Shows persistence and confidence in his observation, trying to convince others to investigate.
Leaves the room reluctantly and complies when told to go to bed, indicating respect for authority despite disappointment.
Runs toward the house quickly and alerts his mother about the strange buzzing sound he felt in the field, showing concern and responsiveness.
Expresses uncertainty and hesitancy when describing the buzzing sound to his mother, indicating sincerity and a lack of exaggeration or dishonesty.
Responds breathlessly and somewhat anxiously to his mother's concern, demonstrating emotional openness and trustworthiness in communicating his feelings.
Notices a high-frequency hum and trembling ground, trusts his perception and runs toward the house to get help.
Expresses uncertainty about the buzzing sound but shares his observations despite his unsure feelings.
Does not take immediate direct action to investigate further or search for his father beyond running to get help.
Insists on going out to look for the missing persons despite his mother's warnings and concern.
Stands looking out the window, showing alertness to the situation outside.
Shows concern for his father and asks relevant questions about his absence and injury.
Leans over the back of his father's chair and stares intently, indicating a probing but respectful approach.
Does not challenge his father's vague and evasive answers about the injury or his absence.
Staggers away after being slapped by his father; later obeys and leaves to play with Cricket despite the harsh treatment.
Observes intently through a telescope, showing curiosity and attention to detail.
Reacted with a puzzled expression upon seeing the scar, showing awareness and critical observation.
Runs toward the field to help after a little girl is taken, then hesitates and runs back toward the house, showing concern but also indecision.
Hesitates and responds nervously when confronted by John MacLean, shows vulnerability and a desire to avoid conflict.
Approaches Mrs. Wilson to inform her about Kathy, showing concern for her safety.
Approaches cautiously, admits to hiding in bushes while observing, causing Mrs. Wilson to become alarmed.
Knocks on the door and tries to explain an unusual event to Mrs. Wilson, showing initiative and attempting to gather help or information.
Feels compelled to hide in the bushes with his telescope, indicating preparation and observation skills.
Struggles to clearly communicate his story to Mrs. Wilson and backs away when she becomes hostile, showing some uncertainty or lack of confidence.
Persistently attempts to convince Mrs. Wilson of a bizarre event despite her disbelief, showing determination but potentially poor social judgment.
Tries to explain the strange situation to Mrs. Wilson honestly despite her aggression.
Raises his elbow to ward off slaps from Mrs. Wilson instead of reacting aggressively.
Sidles around to look at the back of Kathy's head, showing concern.
Responds flatly with 'I'm sorry' when Mrs. Wilson accuses him of scaring her.
Calls out to warn Mrs. Wilson that her house is on fire.
Declines offered cookies and milk politely but does not express any harshness.
Coordinates with Arthur Turner to help put out the fire by managing the hose nozzle.
Suggests Mrs. Wilson call the fire department, showing concern for her well-being.
Persists in trying to see the Chief of Police despite initial dismissal, speaks pleadingly and honestly about his concerns.
Pauses with indecision before resolving to act and walks quickly to address the issue.
Pleads to see the Chief of Police despite the sergeant's refusal, shows persistence in pursuing an important matter.
Unable to clearly state the nature of his business initially, saying 'you wouldn't believe me' and hesitating.
Earnestly reports disturbing events to the Chief of Police, showing sincerity and trust in authority.
Pleading urgently to the Chief not to call his father, revealing vulnerability and trust.
Nervously biting his lips while the Chief makes calls, indicating anxiety and openness.
Passive actions such as staring through detention room window, possibly indicating resignation or reflection.
Clearly explains his observations to the Chief of Police, showing careful attention and willingness to report unusual events.
Shows nervousness and fear when the Chief calls his father despite his plea, indicating some lack of confidence or control in the situation.
Observes and reacts to details (like the Chief's red spot) carefully, demonstrating awareness and attention to subtle clues.
Shows visible terror and clings to his dog Cricket, frantically protesting when told Cricket will be taken away.
Pulls away from Pat's gentle attempt to comfort him, backs away from people trying to reassure him.
Feeds a piece of sandwich to his dog Cricket, showing care and kindness.
Speaks to Dr. Blake in a scared voice, showing vulnerability and trust.
Asks the Doctor to talk to his mother about his father's change, showing honesty and openness.
Runs to his mother and expresses gladness that she is here
Stares at his mother and backs away when she detaches his hands coldly
David stares incredulously at his mother after she speaks unsympathetically to him and leaves.
Incessantly discusses imaginative and science fiction stories with adults despite others viewing this negatively.
Shows incredulity and keen observation by staring at his mother as she leaves, following her intently.
Provides accurate and detailed information about his aunt's name and address promptly when asked.
Politely refuses to amuse himself with magazines but accepts them with thanks.
Explains the Focault pendulum to Pat, then adjusts explanation upon realizing Pat is an amateur.
Interacts with Professor Kelston, who affectionately puts hand on David's shoulder, implying David is friendly and well-liked.
Expresses concern about his missing mother's suitcase and father's rifle, offers to take Fielding to see Kathy Wilson.
Stands by quietly as Mrs. Wilson is distraught and nervous, showing no dismissiveness or impatience.
Politely answers the phone and promptly calls Colonel Fielding to take the call.
Eagerly expresses desire to participate because he discovered the whole thing, showing enthusiasm and respect for authority.
Accepts Fielding's orders to wait and leave his dog behind without complaint, showing obedience and trust.
Grabs Sergeant Balardi's arm to prevent him from firing, possibly avoiding friendly fire or rash action.
Picks up Balardi's fallen pistol after he is knocked down.
Looks uncertain at tunnel intersection but chooses a path to follow soldiers taking Balardi.
Picks up pistol after soldier knocks Balardi down, takes initiative to pursue soldiers and Balardi by running after them.
Pauses uncertainly at tunnel intersection, unsure which way to go before finally choosing a direction.
Desperately digging at the tunnel wall to escape before demolition, showing determination and concern.
Desperately digs at the tunnel wall to reach the trapdoor under extreme time pressure.
Despite exhaustion and sweat, continues to persevere skillfully toward the objective.
Reaches the tunnel roof, skillfully pushes open the trapdoor, and climbs out confidently while under pressure.
Successfully escapes through the trapdoor and is promptly rescued by Fielding who brings him to safety without hesitation.
Walks slowly up the hill and picks up a small piece of metal, putting it in his pocket.
Walks aimlessly toward the mutants, examines a piece of metal, then throws it aside before noticing something else.
Shows concern for his parents' wellbeing, asks if they are all right anxiously.
Turns to his aunt with worry, seeks reassurance about his parents' condition.
Speaks disgustedly about the nurse feeding Cricket toast and spinach instead of real food.
Follows instructions and leaves quietly with his aunt and dog without protest.
Responds politely and cooperatively to Aunt Margaret's bedtime routine, exchanging warm goodnight wishes.
Shows concern for his dog Cricket when the dog growls and looks out the window.
Makes quick adjustments of the ocular and uses the telescope efficiently to observe unusual phenomena.
Clutches Cricket and stares out the window, expressing surprise without immediate action.
Observes the strange fireball with awe but proceeds to take action by putting on his robe and slippers and following the dog outside to investigate.
Stops suddenly when the dog growls and does not rashly continue forward alone into an unknown potentially dangerous area.
Runs back to the house and quickly retrieves a flashlight before re-entering the hall, showing preparedness.
Swallows the medicine despite knowing he is not sick, showing compliance and patience.
Insists confidently that he saw a flying saucer and tries to convince his father logically.
Shows concern for Blossom by suggesting they should go check on her immediately.
Allows himself to be pushed back and told to go to sleep despite maintaining his belief, showing limited assertiveness in face of doubt.
Feels the effects of a sedative and yawns, showing fatigue and limited alertness.
Complies quietly and patiently with his father's instructions to go to sleep, showing calmness and composure.
Walks hesitantly into the field with Cricket the next morning to investigate possible disturbances, indicating cautiousness but some willingness to engage the situation.
Rushed toward his father with concern, asked what happened to him.
Leans over father's chair to question him about where he was.
Runs toward the field when he sees danger, showing initial courage and quick reaction.
Stops with indecision then turns and runs back toward the house, indicating hesitation and lack of confidence in handling the situation.
Hesitates and stammers when talking to John MacLean, unable to provide clear answers, showing a lack of assertiveness and confidence.
Ultimately complies and leaves quietly when confronted, avoiding confrontation but also not taking charge.
Raises his elbow to ward off Mrs. Wilson's blows, shows awareness and self-defense in a stressful situation.
Attempts to provide important information about the space ship and underground threat despite disbelief from Mrs. Wilson.
Sidles around awkwardly to look at the back of Kathy's head instead of directly confronting the situation.
Appears flustered and frantically tries to explain, lacking calm and controlled communication.
Apologizes flatly after causing panic, showing some social awareness and responsibility.
Notices smoke coming from cellar, quickly calls out to alert Mrs. Wilson the house is on fire.
Points and holds hose steady for neighbor to attach and use effectively.
Tells Mrs. Wilson to call the fire department promptly.
Refuses cookies and milk after tense interaction, demonstrating restraint.
Suggests to Mrs. Wilson that she should call the fire department during a fire incident.
Sidlies around Kathy and watches her closely, showing suspicion or careful observation.
Attempts to call Professor Kelston and politely hangs up when no one is available.
Quietly hides behind phone booth door to avoid being seen by his father and keeps Cricket from barking.
Suggests involving his mother to shed light on the situation, showing insight and initiative.
Observes Blake and Pat's heads for scars, then relaxes after confirming none, showing perceptiveness and critical thinking.
Asks if Blake has talked to his mother, indicating engagement and follow-through.
Appears resigned when doubted, showing some lack of confidence or difficulty in persuasion.
Runs eagerly to greet his mother, showing emotional impulsiveness rather than measured behavior.
Returns to the chair and sits slowly after his mother detaches from him coldly, showing hesitation and discomfort in a tense social situation.
Provides detailed information about his aunt and thanks Dr. Blake politely.
Speaks hesitantly about his strange experience, worried that others will think he is crazy.
Acknowledges his discomfort but continues to share his observations sincerely with Blake and Kelston.
Takes the lead in explaining an unusual observation despite feeling uncomfortable and fearing disbelief.
Hesitates and stammers when beginning to explain his observations.
Confidently and sincerely shares his observation through the telescope, trying to be helpful and truthful.
Excitedly recalls a previous friendly interaction with Kelston about looking through the telescope at his mother cooking supper.
Accurately identifies and describes the location and incident using his telescope, provides confident and precise observational details.
Demonstrates excitement but maintains focus on providing useful information to adult authorities.
Relies on a one-inch, fifty-power telescope while others have more powerful instruments, yet his observation proves valid and valuable.
Identifies his father's car and notices someone with him using the telescope, showing attentiveness and situational awareness.
Follows the actions through the telescope and points out where the man is walking, demonstrating careful observation skills.
Calls multiple times on the phone to try to reach someone, showing persistence.
Does not provide any new information or suggestions in the discussion about the Martians and the rocket.
Asks to stop by the hospital to get his dog.
Waits patiently in the driveway while others make calls and arrangements.
Suggests stopping by the hospital to get his dog, showing practical concern for personal matters amid tense circumstances.
Runs up the driveway promptly and waits attentively for Fielding to join him, demonstrating readiness and engagement.
Relays observation that the car is not at the house, indicating situational awareness.
Notices that his mother's suitcase and father's rifle are missing and reports it, showing awareness of potential issues.
Offers to take Fielding to talk to Kathy Wilson about the fire incident, demonstrating initiative and helpfulness.
Stands perturbed in front of the closet, showing some emotional disturbance but no clear action to resolve it.
Adjusts the monocular correctly to identify specific landmarks and assists Fielding with precise observations.
Stands frozen thinking about his parents' fate instead of taking immediate action or reporting new information.
Responds clearly to Fielding's question about the creature despite difficulty in seeing it clearly.
Nods concerned affirmation when Fielding identifies the trapdoor, showing awareness and confirmation rather than confusion.
Follows Fielding promptly when he runs toward the field after spotting the trapdoor, demonstrating alertness and readiness to act.
Identifies that Sergeant Balardi has been caught by observing the ground and alerting Fielding.
Reluctantly follows orders but shows polite military discipline when corrected.
Expresses disappointment about leaving the scene and going back to hospital.
Keeps some distance from the main group, watching from afar.
Initially questions the reason for going back to the hospital, showing reluctance and hesitation.
Straightens up militarily and complies with Fielding's order to return to the hospital.
Straggles behind Pat and looks back reluctantly while walking, indicating lack of urgency and hesitance.
Slowly regains consciousness and sits up, rubbing his eyes in a dazed manner.
Reacts in terror at seeing Pat being placed upon the operating table and tries to stop it by screaming and starting to his feet.
Is quickly restrained by a mutant with a hand clamped over his mouth, preventing further action or communication.
Runs toward the dead end of the tunnel and stops, looking about uncertainly.
Climbs to the top of the slope at the dead end and peers up at the roof.
Identifies a faint outline of a possible trapdoor and attempts to reach it despite physical difficulty.
Tries to dig into a hard earthen wall with bare fingers before improvising a digging tool by using his belt buckle and belt.
Responds promptly to the dog's alert, quickly gets out of bed to investigate the unusual sight at night, and uses his telescope skillfully to observe the phenomenon.
